title: not actually useful
body:
Hello. I am quite disappointed with the service I received.
I originally self referred and eventually got a phone call to "triage" my situation
at that time i was told to go to a private counsellor and no help could be given
then after that initial disappointment i was called back to after 5-10 minutes say that i WOULD be offered some help possibly some cbt ( i assumed)
and to await a further appointment and to fill in a GAD PHQ WSAS form, which i did
i was informed that i would talk through the results with the consultant to help with going forward
after todays talk it felt like i was triaged again and again told that private therapy was my only option.
we didnt go through anything on the form and the disjointed conversation was upsetting
while I appreciate that these are difficult times, its hard on me to be denied help and then offered hope of help and then denied again
all with nerve wracking waits in-between and cancelled appointments
I am left with only a go private option which with my mental health problems hindering this process
and no further help, advice on ongoing support even if this would be a long wait or waiting for circumstance to change with covid etc.
i have been nerve wracked waiting and considering the problems i have to talk though with someone
that your services specifically called me back to say that i WOULD be offered some help
it makes me feel worse and more suicidal, its pointless trying to get from our national health service
maybe there is not much or anything you can do for me or people in my situation
but bungling these actually important communications is not great
i feel l like i am in a worse situation than before

I'm sorry but you could improve even if you cant actually help people that require your services given the current situation

author: LD84
title: The hospital has failed to advise
body:
I understand the NHS has been under tremendous pressure over the last few months. However, my mum was admitted to Hairmyres in June 2020. First of all, paramedics took my mum from her house and failed to explain anything to my dad. She was admitted and the first contact from the hospital was to advise she was “very unwell” she was being asked to sign a DNR, as they said it would be cruel to try and bring her back, and they’d call during the night if she deteriorated.  
Can you imagine receiving that call for your 65 year old wife/mother?! Harrowing does not cover it.  
The hospital has so far failed to advise:  
1. Why my mother fell unwell  
2. If she is at risk of it again  
3. What medication she is now receiving  
4. How she ACTUALLY IS rather than just saying “comfortable night”  
My sister and I have just spoken to her on the phone and she is breathless and uncomfortable. Why is she being left like this?! She is currently on the ward at Hairmyres and this is just not on!! I get the distinct impression there is a lack of care and treatment and I want to know why. Is this where our NHS is now?!

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Sue36
title: MRI Scan suffer with claustrophobia
body:
Been having anxiety since last Thursday when I was told I needed an MRI to try and get to the bottom off my knee pain.  
My daughter took me but was not allowed in with me but she calmed me as much as she could, the two Radiographers who work their were so great made me fill at ease and kept reassuring me they were lovely  
Sien & Yannick Need to be recognised by their boss.

author: Evaree
title: Birth
body:
I went to hospital at 40 weeks to be induced and spiked a temp. I was put into a room on my own as they suspected covid. A member of staff was monitoring my baby and left me on the machine for 3 hours, I kept telling them I needed the toilet they said no I have 2 stay on the monitor and to think about my baby. I was in so much pain I kept telling them and they did not listen.  
After 3hours a doctor checked my cervix and my waters had broke and I was at 4cm and my baby was distressed. They monitored my baby for 12 hours. The next day after a painful night and 3 failed epidurals they decided I needed a emergency csection.  
After the birth I wasnt allowed to see my baby, my partner asked a staff member if he could go home and get a shower and come back they said yes it was ok. Once he went they came in and told me he couldnt come back now hes gone. I met my son the next day and he was on antiboitics through a drip later in the day he needed it topping up and the childrens ward did not want him on the ward as I was suspected covid and they wouldnt come into my room either it was very stressful. One of the staff spoke to them and they sent someone over to do it outside my room.  
My test came back covid negative and I had a infection somewhere they did xrays, ultrasounds but they did not do a vaginal swab. I blame it on not letting me get up to go to the toilet. My son was jaundice it was a scary situation for me being a first time mum all alone. He had treatment in the incubator and was screamimg and not breathing right he was scared so they brought a mat light down for him to lay on. Later in the night a member of staff came in and said another baby needs that light he will have to go im the incubator I said my son needs this he stopped breathing in the incubator they said if you dont let me take it childrens ward will take it. I begged and begged, in the end they found one somewhere else.  
I did want more children but after this happening I cannot go through that ever again some of the staff members were very rude on the recovery ward I would never recommend anyone to have their baby here after my experience.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: DaisyChain75
title: Diagnosis pathway
body:
I moved to Crewe in May 2019. My son was 6 years old at the time (he's now 7, nearly 8) my family and I came from Telford, where he was on a waiting list for a diagnosis process for ADHD which wasn't going to proceed for a long long time due to staffing issues. Once we moved to Crewe, I had a referral in place for him immediately. I waited a couple of months and finally got his initial appointment expedited due to the nature and severity of his symptoms. He was seen in August 2019 after his appointment was expedited. His current school and myself, then waited a month before we got the infamous 'Connor's questionnaire', which were promptly filled in by both of us. Time ticked on and I hadn't heard anything going into January. I phoned the paediatric team, who told me they acknowledged the forms in December and that the next step on my son's diagnosis pathway would be about 6 months from then taking it to about June time.  
Sometime in February before Coronavirus lockdown came about, I asked the team to please expedite his appointment again (after all, there was obviously a reason for his first one to be so urgent). I was told I'd need a GP to write to them to confirm reasons. First GP I asked refused to get involved. I then asked another who sent correspondence regarding my concerns. I heard nothing, so contacted the team again who told me they couldn't even see any correspondence and that if they thought his appointment should be expedited again from what the doctor wrote, then they would have done. I waited yet again, then lockdown occurred. I contacted them again only to be told they were now only dealing with already medicated patients!! I asked another GP to write to them and I STILL haven't heard anything!!!!!! He should have been seen by now and I know that Coronavirus/Covid-19 has turned the whole world upside down, but to hear nothing at all is EXTREMELY irritating. In the meantime, I have found out, they only want to go down the ASD diagnosis route and not ADHD too which is absurd! Nobody in Telford would even acknowledge he had ASD traits and only wanted to diagnose ADHD. I'm mum and I know he struggles with both disorders.  
The outcome for him, was to medicate to hopefully help control his impulsivity etc. which is of major concern.  
There seems to be nowhere I can turn to to be able to help him. PALS haven't even replied to me.  
To get no response at all from anywhere or anyone is very worrying and my family and I feel really let down.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Mid Cheshire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great Service
body: The care I received from the Urology team was great.  They showed a lot of care and kept in touch and informed me of everything that needed to be done.  I was grateful to them for showing care in looking after me.

title: Accepting the Coronavirus crisis but ..
body: Telephone access is appalling and staff appear dismissive and certainly elderly patients are at a massive disadvantage

title: Excellent holistic practice
body: I visited today 30/6 2020 having fallen in to a river whilst fishing when a hook embedded in to my thumb. The staff were very efficient and cared for me, by not just removing the hook, but comforted me showing sympathy and talked to me to comfort me through out the removal of the hook. As a nurse myself, i was very impressed of their professionalism. Many thanks, Dave

title: Castle Practice-A Great Practice
body: Over my 68 years of life I have seen many GP Practices, all over the UK. The Castle Practice is by far the best! The first thing to say is that when you need a doctor the reception staff will try to get an appointment for you, they may ask a few questions but this is only so they can place you with the right doctor and not just anyone! When you see a doctor they will give you time and supply you with the correct advice/treatment, or directed you through the necessary steps to complete the treatment. The support staff are always ready to listen and help people and do so in a caring manner! It's very easy to make a complaint, and sometimes the answer is not the one a patient wants, but at the Castle Practice they will leave no stone unturned to try to solve an issue. They show compassion and really care about their patients! During this unique time of Covid 19, Corona Virus, the Castle Practice has given over the surgery as a Covid Unit and all of the staff included the medical team have been running from three different sites. The doctors have used all the technologies at their disposal from their own homes. From telephone, text, email and video, not what we are used to but in these desperate times we have all had to adapt. Castle Practice have made the necessary changes to make sure their patients have the correct and proper care. I my case they have ensured that when we have asked for repeat prescriptions they have made certain that our local Paydens Chemist have been able supply our medical needs.To the whole team at the Castle Practice - Thank You all!

title: Good services
body: I had a smear test and the lady was so cooperative a d helpful. I was so happy and it was comfortable experience.

title: thank you and well done
body: i have attended for INR blood tests throughout these challenging times. I have found staff taking on board all the government guidelines ,premises felt safe with excellent information given prior to visit , well done and thank you to all staff in attendance and those working from home

title: Bad experience
body: I have been to a&e roughly 4 times over the last 3 years due to on going health issues. The A&E department is horrible when it comes to patient care. They're like a high school clique, you can hear them gossiping. They also seem very judgemental too. This has been whenever I have visited. It’s really unfortunate. They’re much better in the wards itself. This should be looked into. Being in A&E is unpleasant as it is, no one wants to go willingly. But the least you would expect is nice nurses and doctors. It’s a really uncomfortable place. I have never left a review in my life for anything but I just had to for this. Can we please get more professionalism. Thanks

title: Great Practice
body: Helpful, friendly staff.  Very impressed with the new e-consult option on the website.  Easy to use.  Sent my details through in the evening and had a callback from the Dr in the morning.

title: Great building poor face mask control
body:
I am deeply concerned that on my visit of the 30th June, that there was no enforcement of face covering use at this NHS location.
This is contrary to current Covid-19 instructions.
Please review so it is safe for vulnerable persons to visit when they must.

title: Thank you but.....
body:
I had an appointment for cancer investigations on 30th June at the urology out patients clinic .  Everyone was very professional.  When I arrived in the clinic I was asked questions about coronavirus and had my temperature taken.  The nurses were very friendly, professional and helpful.  The appointment went well.  The doctor explained everything clearly and answered my questions.  Later in the day I had a scan which reduces my need to go back.  I am very pleased with how things were handled and my care.  Thank you.

When I arrived and left I did notice that hospital staff were eating, drinking and using their phones without masks in the main area at the far end of the hospital.  I asked the receptionist about this and was told that people shouldn't be eating there as everyone is meant to wear masks but it keeps happening.  Sadly a disappointing blip to what was in other ways a very positive experience at a concerning time.

title: Chandos Surgery CLOSED
body: I had a text from the surgery to say a long term medical condition was overdue for review and I needed to arrange an appointment as matter of urgency. I rang up and was told they had shut the Chandos surgery ! I would have to travel to Woodhouse. Not a very good idea at this time! I can’t believe they have shut our local surgery at a time when you are not meant to travel. Why have local patients been abandoned by the surgery? A lot of the local patients are elderly and need a local surgery not one miles away. Are you wanting to stop offering a service in this area? If so we need to know not have this done by stealth!

author: Papa Jim
title: Care at home after discharge from hospital.
body:
I came home after being in the critical care unit with flu a in one lung and the corona virus in the other lung, I was very weak as I'd been ill for 3 weeks at home then 3/4 weeks in hospital. I wasn't strong enough to stand in the over the bath shower and after 3weeks of trying for help and being told I wasn't an urgent case my daughter heard about stars and contacted them.  
An OT Katey came to assess my situation. After a pleasant but thorough assessment was over Katey left and returned 15mins later with a bath board and later that day a leaning chair to enable me to shave etc at the sink arrived which made such a difference to, not just my physical health but also my mental health. Katey kept in regular touch to make sure I had what I needed to make life easier and gave advice to help me on my way to recovery. Everything was done in a friendly professional way, and we will be forever grateful to Stars and Katey.

title: Excellent Practice
body: Spoke with a lovely receptionist who called me back within 10 minutes of registration online. Extremely quick and efficient. I then had the doctor call me back within 10 minutes of the phone registration who confirmed my skin prescription within 10 minutes. I have never had such an experience with my previous health centre - always having to wait weeks and sometimes months for an appointment. Couldn’t recommend highly enough!

title: Excellent telephone service
body: I spoke to reception yesterday to arrange a telephone consultation with a doctor for a small but very troublesome problem.  Within a couple of hours a GP phoned me, knew exactly what to prescribe and sent my prescription to the local pharmacy.  The telephone service was excellent, no wasting time and no sitting waiting at the surgery.  I hope this telephone consultation service continues.  Very well done!

title: Poor practice
body:
Would you please explain why the cost of a medical has increased to £150.00, as I paid £95.00 last year.
The procedure is basically a tick box exercise, apart from taking my blood pressure and a basic eye test. Last years appointment was during surgery hours.

title: Worst practice ever
body: I’ve been waiting more than 40 minutes on the phone and after it was my turn the phone was just ringing shout an answer. They taking break and leave the line open so it looks like they’re busy. Totally unprofessional and unreliable. Also appointments are a nightmare, nothing but bad experience and headaches.

title: Caring & great practice
body:
I would like to thank the Bradford-on-Avon Surgery for their kindness and empathy when I visited the surgery with my issue. The Practice was very reassuring however owing to the location they did recommend a referral to be on safe side. Not only did they guide me with it they also followed up as they said they would. I know these maybe standard practice but I really feel that the wonderful staff at Bradford on Avon deserve praise especially during these incredibly stressful times. 
We feel safe and cared for which is priceless. 
Thank you for being so great. 
Kind regards 
Caroline

author: Nowhere to Turn
title: Zero contact from Dermatology
body:
I am seriously concerned that my daughter mental and physical health has deteriorated in the last 2 weeks due to her severe eczema. She was undergoing phototherapy at ARI which was going well and it was cut short due to Covid-19.  
Her skin started to get really bad and her GP prescribed oral steroids for 5 weeks, as soon as the dose got down to about 2 per day her skin flared again. She called her GP again and was asked “what is it you would like me to do for you?”. We tried to find out From the Dermatology dept at ARI if and when the phototherapy would re-start and the receptionist could not tell us. They suggested we call the out-patient co-ordination but no one answered after trying numerous times.  
I spent the day with my daughter in June and was alarmed at her mental state and also her condition, she was constantly shaking, her heart was racing and her skin was oozing. My husband and I decided to take her to A and E where she stayed for 3 days. Not once did the dermatologist see her or even speak to her!  
The hospital prescribed more steroids and sent her home but these have not helped. They told her the dermatologist could not be contacted and could not guarantee they would be in touch! She has not slept properly for more than 2 weeks and despite calling her GP on Friday and asking for them to ensure someone from Dermatology phone us that day we are still waiting!  
It is not an understatement to say I am desperate to get someone to help her but I don’t know where to turn.

title: Excellent staff
body: Visited hospital for x-ray and came across 5 nursing staff. All were fantastic, all came across as friendly and professional. Everyone had a smile on their face and appeared to enjoy there work. Can't recommend them highly enough.

author: Wenbs75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Lockdown bereavement
body:
I just wanted to extend my thanks to the paramedic team and the team within the A&E department at Ninewells.  
My elderly father took unwell in the early hours one day at the end of March and was taken by a wonderful team of paramedics to Ninewells Hospital. Although it took almost an hour for an ambulance to arrive once it did the team acted swiftly and compassionately towards my Dad who was desperately ill by this time.  
Obviously with Covid restrictions I was unable to accompany him to the hospital which was very distressing not only for myself but also for my father.  
Once at Ninewells the consultant Alistair who cared for my father kept me fully updated as to his condition and also had to make the very difficult phone call to me to tell me that sadly my father had passed away.  
Alistair explained that I would be allowed in to see my Dad but unfortunately I myself had tested positive for Covid 19 and was unable to see my father in hospital so my last memory of my Dad was him leaving to go to Ninewells  
I cannot praise the staff enough who looked after my father at what must have been an extremely difficult and frightening time for them all and to have to advise families of a death under these restrictive circumstances must be very upsetting. Even after my fathers death Alistair contacted me again later in the day to ensure that I was okay and I also got the opportunity to speak to Paula the nurse who held my Dads hand as he died. Her words and those of Alistair have been a huge source of comfort to me to know that my Dad was not alone and someone was with him has helped me hugely.  
I have worked for NHS Tayside for over 20 years and am incredibly proud to work for an organisation that has shown determination and true courage in facing and managing this pandemic.  
I will forever be indebted to these incredible individuals for making a heartbreaking situation a little bit easier.

author: larjag
title: Melenoma care in lockdown
body:
I was diagnosed with stage 3 mestasis melenoma at the end of February and despite the pending lockdown this worked in my favour in terms of the speed of care offered. I was already reviewed by the melenoma clinic  
And had first hand experience of the excellent, person centred and dedicated care offered by Advance melenoma Nurse Ashleigh who has been a god send for the last few years but in particular 2020 no words or amount of thanks could describe how grateful I am for the support she has given me emotionally and also her response to my physical care and treatment has been consistently attentive, informative and proactive. Ashleigh is very active in engaging me in my care plan and respond promptly to any phone and email communication. If there was a nomination for a nursing award she would 100% get my vote as she is everything I would hope from a nursing practitioner and more.  
My consultant Mr Rahman worked closely with Ashleigh and I seen scans, tests and surgery all actioned within two weeks of confirming recurrence.  
I had my surgery in March and thereafter was cared for in plastics and burns. The staff from cleaning staff, health care assistances and amazing nurses, doctors and consultants have almost become my second family during lockdown having spent 12 days post surgery as an i patient followed by a Series of outpatient Appointments at dressings clinics. Then due to a infection A further week in April and three weeks in June back on ward 214.  
The only thing I can say about all staff of 214 is that they are AMAZING, they clearly work well as a team and the ethos they have created in Their ward is felt and is incomparable to any previous hospital care I have received.  
All nursing staff are very person centred and as well as offering highly competent and attentive physical care they take time to chat and ensure emotional well-being If patients. Their is a nice feel to the whole ward and even when busier this care has not faltered. Nothing ever feels to much to ask of them and they actively encourage you to buzz them whenever help is needed. The nurses are friendly, approachable and warm In their practice and are very informative and Strong advocates in ensuring I was well informed in my care plan.  
All my stays have been during lockdown and I am aware this has brought all kinds of hurdles to be navigated however this isn’t obvious to patients, they offer inclusive care and were able to offer regular support and updates to my Family when I felt to unwell to do so and this was over and above their role but so very appreciated and instrumental in my recovery.  
Being a patient isn’t something one hopes or plans for especially for 6 weeks however I have felt so well cared for and my Ongoing recovery Has only been achievable thanks to the melenoma and plastics team. I have got to know the staff during this period and joke that they are now my lockdown family having seen them more than anyone outwith my household.  
Whilst I am looking forward to getting home and returning to care as an outpatient this review is only a small bit of my gratitude and I hope that anyone who is due similar surgery or care in ward 214 feels reassured that they will be in safe and caring hands of a highly person centred, skilled and caring multidisciplinary team.  
Thank you all so very much.

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Dont reccomend this hospital.
body: I am 34 weeks pregnant I went into the hospital on Saturday with bleeding. I was checked and was loosing blood and clots. Had test and was positive for labour. Was admitted to the ward to be observed. Was just left all the time with nobody even checking. Was telling them my problems and wasnt listening. Had to ask for bed to be changed and fresh water all the time, had monitors on baby some she wasnt okay on. Had to always be kept waiting around was told Tuesday they was delivering my baby via section but because no beds and no cot was free they wasnt able to do it.... not a very good service at all went from bad to worse.

title: It’s alright
body: Bell house there some good doctors which you can’t even get a appointment from but then on the other hand there are some totally rubbish doctors that don’t help you with giving good advice but meanwhile whenever you say your symptoms to them they think it’s cause of coronavirus For everything then be like go and have a test for the symptoms then I said it’s no where even near the coronavirus symptoms and not even helping enough I’m so fed up with some certain doctors Like think before you say something everything it’s not always due to the coronavirus outcomes Seriously next time need better help than this and have good service.

title: Good practice
body:
Best practices! Always helpful
Listens atententively 
U can call and talk to a very helpful team. 
The telephone appointments are real useful an done timidly mannor

title: Cant get an appointment with a gp
body: I myself understand first hand the difficulties faced in gp practice as I'm a practice nurse myself however I feel my service today is unacceptable. I've held off from calling the doctors for an appointment for this reason but could no longer leave my symptoms untreated. After being on hold for 1 hour and 34 mins awaiting an answer from tickhill surgery I phoned the colliery line who answered. I was told tickhill are very busy and it's normal to have to wait that long. I explained I would like a telephone call with a gp (knowing appts are restricted at the moment). I was told there are none left for today and to call in the morning tomorrow. I'm relatively young and fit and have alternative options. However I feel sorry for the elderly community who have no choice but to use this service where they cant get an appt. I know that once i get an appointment the gp service will be perfect as it always is but something needs doing about the management system

author: Imharrison
title: Express thanks for pre-assessment
body: I would like to express my thanks to the pre assessment staff in Victoria Hospital for their very professional and calming approach towards me at my appointment this morning. Keep up the good work.

title: Time waste
body:
I was allowed to book a cholesterol blood test for 10:00am, i attended the appointment, i was seeing at 10:30 and the nurse denied me the blood test telling me i needed a doctor referral.
I then called the doctor who told me i was not allowed to have a routine blood test. There was not apologies and it was clearly a surgery mistake. I wasted lots of time after a 10 hour night shift in a care home. Very disorganised

title: Parking Nightmare
body: Parking facilities at this hospital are atrocious & have now been exacerbated further by allowing staff to park in car parks dedicated for visitors. You need to resolve this situation & quick !

readBy.name: Royal United Hospital Bath NHS Trust

title: Phone always engaged
body: 1/7/20 Been calling since 1100hrs to talk to the pharmacy and the phone is continually engaged, its allways like this

author: Elm Ward Service User
title: They all have a heart of gold
body:
To the managers of Elm Ward in the Western Trust (Omagh),  
To mention a few would be hard because every single nurse, doctor and occupational therapist have been nothing short of amazing. They always made me feel as comfortable as possible by changing my bed and making my room like a cosy wee place to relax.  
When I cried they comforted me like a mother would comfort her child. They made small jokes to make me laugh when I didn't feel it was possible. From the smiley face in the dining room to the simple "Hi, are you ok? " they will never understand how it lifted my mood.  
The nurses always checked and simply made it out of kindness of the heart as opposed to their job. They never made their job look hard and I couldn't choose more suitable for the job. They have the softest voices and the most infectious laughs! They always have a smile on their face and a welcoming rub on your back to give me the encouragement to make the extra step into recovery - and I can say wholeheartedly that they are the reason my smile shines on.  
They all have a heart of gold and a wonderful way of helping people. I will never forget the medical help I got but most importantly the tender, loving care. I won't ever forget the kindest, most caring staff in there. They have truly positively impacted my life and I want them to receive every thanks and happiness always.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Content partner
title: Thanks to Staff
body: Would like to thank all staff on ward 10 as a respiratory ward and all staff who moved from ward 17 for their care and attention showed over many years to my husband could not be kinder.

author: chillychaz
title: Excellent Day Care
body:
My Mother usually attends Sheen Lane day centre. Always well cared for and encouraged to join in group activities.  
Mum always says how much she enjoys going.  
Staff always help when she has appointments which I find difficult to manage in time.  
During COVID the centre has been shut but staff continue to call and check on her.

title: Amazing Amwell Practice
body: I cannot speak highly enough of this practice and all the staff. My 94 year old mother has received care and treatment above and beyond with all the doctors going the extra mile to help her. I cannot praise them enough.

author: jackpotkx88
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Overall very impressed
body: I am very impressed with the attention I have received. I did not expect all of the help I have had. I didn't get anywhere near as much as this when I had a heart attack. Overall very impressed. Speech therapy and Occupational Therapy were both good.

readBy.name: Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

author: Emmrd63
title: IMHA Service
body:
Huw,  
Thank you for your support, it’s made a huge difference already.

author: kilojw53
title: My recovery
body:
I was in addiction and my life in every aspect was falling apart.  
Scared lonely confused and with little confidence I made the decision to go to halton cgl

author: Doods
title: Infection Prevention & Control Standards in Hospital.
body:
I had an unexpected emergency admission to hospital in May 2020 and I spent 3 nights as an inpatient across 2 hospitals, ie Wishaw General and Hairmyers. I have to admit I was really scared going into any hospital but as I had suffered a heart attack I had absolutely no choice.  
On the whole i noticed a bit of a step-up in relation to infection Prevention & Control practices in general but, in the short time I was an in-patient I witnessed several different events where the practices of medical staff would definitely have spread Covid-19 if it had been present in the wards.......and who knows really whether it was or not?  
The concerns relevant to Wishaw General are as follows:  
No new patients were screened for Covid-19 on admission. I know this because I wasn’t and when I asked others they confirmed that they weren’t either. On admission to the A&E department I expressed my fear and I was told “Don’t worry, you’ll be fine, there’s no Covid in here” How do they know that if they weren’t checking new people coming in? To make sure I was as safe as possible I requested that I go into a side room.  
There were clear notices up on walls in side rooms in A&E telling staff to remove PPE before leaving the room.......not once was this rule followed! And I’m not just talking about nurses, senior medical practitioners were just as bad! I find this very concerning. As a senior manager of a reputable Care at Home provider I teach Infection Prevention and Control procedures to Social Care staff and failure to follow Health Protection Scotland (HPS) guidelines on appropriate use, donning of and disposal of used PPE is considered a very serious risk to patient/client health and safety.........and then I find myself blatantly exposed to this same risk!  
When in the Emergency Care Ward where visitors are not supposed to be allowed in I witnessed a relative of one patient being allowed in to set up their relative’s phone charger (I believe it was Grandparent/Grandchild) And not only this, but after the visitor was let in they discovered they had brought the wrong phone charger so went away and came back again with the correct one about 30 mins later! This in my opinion was irresponsible and totally unacceptable. I had been rushed into hospital by ambulance so had no opportunity to bring in any essentials I would need. My daughter drove 20 miles from her home to mine and then another 10 miles to Wishaw General to get me basic essentials and she had to hand these to a nurse at the main entrance ........ which is perfectly acceptable in the current climate; why I ask is a visitor allowed right into the ward with a phone charger? I actually overheard the patient asking their visitor how they managed to get in and they said they waved their work ID badge and no-one asked anything. I just hope that same visitor was not in contact with anyone Covid-19 positive as consideration for other patients in the ward was not evident........but then, where were the medical staff’s priorities either?  
It’s all very well the DHSC putting out guidelines which are supposedly there to keep us all safe, but who is monitoring/policing any adherence (or otherwise) to these guidelines in any case? .... from what I have seen it looks like no-one is! It seems that as a patient I was the mercy of the standards and integrity of the person/s looking after me in the ward ..... scary!  
As someone who takes Duty of Care very seriously I expect you not only to investigate my concerns but let me know what steps you will be putting in place to monitor practice! this is the very reason people like me, the general public, do not want to be anywhere near hospitals during the pandemic

author: Heart racing
title: The whole process was so efficient
body: I am a local GP & had two episodes of a very fast heartbeat. A phone all was made to the cardiology hub and I had an appointment within a couple of hours. My nurse Janet was so kind and caring to me. She took my blood & sent them immediately so my results would be back as soon as possible. An ecg was done and Dr Peace, the cardiologist came to talk to me. The whole process was so efficient & as a patient, I felt completely reassured and looked after. It was amazing to not have to sit in A& E for hours and to be seen by experienced clinicians specific to my problem. I am very impressed with this service & will definitely use it for my own patients

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: aquilalk28
title: Inappropriate discharge.
body:
In early 2019 I was allocated a new care co-ordinator. I saw them once and never again. The Psychosis Team were having staffing problems!  
In August 2019 I was allocated another care coordinator. I saw this one only twice. Once with their agenda to discharge my case back to the GP, presumably based on my health records as I had no opportunity to get to know them. I explained that if I was not monitored regarding my medication, then I would obey the voices and stop taking the Olanzapine. I felt that care coordinators would know if I was not taking my medication and section me if I did not. This had been a deterrent in not obeying the voices. My care told them that he would be left picking up the pieces. We got no feedback on this. The feedback that I got was the care coordinator was to discuss with their manager about discharging the case.  
On the next visit in August I was informed by the care coordinator that my case was to be discharged back to the GP. I just gave up! They said they would send me a discharge letter (I never received it until this week, following making a complaint about it). I have not had any annual GP checks stated in it.  
Within the last few weeks I have made an official complaint via PALS about the above.  
Needless to say, it does not take a genius to work out what happened next, I had no perceived deterrent and obeyed the voices, I immediately stopped taking the Olanzapine (it‘s been a year now). I was very firm with my carer and said he needed to keep it to himself or we would fall out big time.  
I went through some terrible withdrawal symptoms for two weeks or so, but persevered: increased amounts of hallucinations, stomach cramps, sweats, head aches, irritability and not sleeping at night (I recently discovered that this could have been life threatening).  
After this I found when I am not having the regular hallucinations I am having periods, when I am functioning intelligibly very well again. I would be extremely resistant to taking anti psychotic medication again and I have overcome any fear of a deterrent anyway.  
Yes, my carer has struggled to help me cope when I have experienced some disturbing hallucinations and when I have heard voices telling me to self harm. I feel he needs more ongoing support with this and is one of my reason for writing to you know.  
During recent weeks I have had a recurring visual, very disturbing hallucination. I am still persevering with this without medication.

readBy.name: Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys NHS Foundation Trust

author: gratefulme
title: You guys are awesome
body:
Huge thank you to Mr Lamb and to Avril the nurse for your kindness and compassion today. And to the other staff members at reception and in area 4 you are so welcoming at a time when safety is a priority during covid.  
Mr Lamb has been a fantastic support to me following complications from my cancer treatment and has made my journey so much easier and for that I thank you. Keep smiling, you guys are awesome.

author: foxlady
title: The Doctor told me I had Cancer
body:
I went to the casualty department of Hairmyres Hospital in East Kilbride in June 2020 where I had a body scan, the Doctor came in the room and told me I had fluid around my heart and problems with my liver and stomach and one of my ovaries.  
The Doctor told me I had Cancer. I was stunned by this and had to wait while tests were done on the fluid removed from my heart. I spent a week in the hospital with what they told me on my mind and feared the worst.  
I was told later in the week there was nothing in it.  
I had more scans and X Rays this assured me there was nothing there.  
I still have this on my mind and find it very hard not to think about it.  
That day in June 2020 will never be forgotten.

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: zebrazh67
title: Rude manner of receptionist
body:
Was due blood test this week. before zoldronate infusion. Halton hosp. Nurse at bloods said not on system but told me it's ok take short cut to Can treat.  
The doors had no sign that I saw, went to receptionist and they stood up shouting, asking where have I come from. loud and nasty told me go back through the door ( that I wasn't supposed come through) go all way to main corridor and walk the circle all way back into where they was at the desk.  
Confused I said are you kidding, I'm stood infront of you. There was no queue. They were very rude shouting they wont do my blood sheet unless I walk all around the corridors. Because I wear glasses I lifted my mask up to let the condensation go. They shouted again, keep your mask on, several times. Right next to them was someone on the computer with a mask round their chin. Not covering their nose & mouth..WOW.  
Now I fully understand you have to have guidelines because of this virus. But to be so nasty and rude. Is not your policy. Really? I was made to feel like a child. Good manners go along way. Needless to say I left and went home.

readBy.name: Warrington and Halton Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: AJBM
title: Midwife care during Covid-19 as a first time mum.
body:
I arrived at hospital and was examined - I was not progressed enough to be admitted to the labour ward but due to needing more pain relief for the contractions I was offered a room on the antenatal ward. Aimee looked after me here and from the moment I met her I felt instantly relaxed in her care. She was warm and friendly and exactly what I needed in those moments, as a first time mum at a hospital alone without my husband during this pandemic! I knew Aimee would take good care of me and ensure I was looked after.  
The hours went on and I progressed enough To be admitted to labour ward where my husband could join us. Luckily for me, Aimee got to stay with us on Labour ward instead of going back to antenatal - this made my day, week, month year!!! My husband and I were over the moon, he could tell how much I trusted Aimee and he also knew I was safe in her care.  
As we went through the night, I was progressing well and using the birth pool and gas and air. Aimee was there with us holding my hand whilst my husband was busy holding the fan and water bottle! My blood pressure increased meaning I needed medication and unfortunately had to leave the pool. This was all explained to me carefully and I understood everything, again Aimee was there with us constantly talking to me and telling me how well I was doing.  
Aimee had to finish her shift around 8am and unexpectedly my labour ended in a c-section at 12:29, when our baby son was born.  
I missed having Aimee there, despite having two other great midwives take care of me, I felt a special connection with Aimee. Luckily she was on the postnatal ward that evening so I saw her again, and again, she was just fantastic. I truly believe she was made to do her job.  
She is a kind and caring person and any woman who meets her and who she helps during labour is extremely lucky. She will always be very special to my husband, son and I.  
Aimee is wonderful at what she does and truly made my experience of labour enjoyable, calm and assuring.  
I had a not so great experience with another member of staff on Postnatal ward the day before I was discharge. I have since been advised that this member of staff is temporarily here to help during Covid-19. Whilst this experience was upsetting for me, it just reaffirmed what amazing care I had received from Aimee and other midwives (Lizzie and Anna included who were  
also lovely!) during my stay in hospital.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Serpico
title: Giving me my life back
body:
Went through my Cardiac Artery Bypass Graft 4 years ago at another hospital, never really felt right when I came out but for 1st year I put everything down to recovery process, still felt unwell for the next 3 years and had issues with GP getting referred back to cardiology. I still felt something just was not right, managed to finally get referral to Hairmyres to do a further treadmill test which showed up some abnormalities, very quick referral to Cath Lab for an angiogram.  
Following the angiogram the consultant discovered a narrowing of the right artery, both left arteries had been bypassed 2016, consultant went straight ahead with inserting a stent and I was released from hospital same day. I already feel much better and the care and attention I received from Cath Lab staff at Hairmyres was second to none and I cannot thank them enough, looking forward to getting my life back from now on!  
Special thanks to Angela who I now consider to be my guardian angel as she has been present at each step of this journey for me and I could not even begin to praise her enough to do her justice, thank you for seeing me through this and giving me my life back!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

title: Front end Voicemail messages (IVR)
body:
I think overall this surgery is great. However, the new front end message is a terrible experience.
Far too long
Difficult to get the system to recognise key presses when you press keys on your phone sometimes needing it to be pressed multiple times.
If you try an option and it is unavailable you have to redial in and don't get the option to choose again. 
Constantly getting told you are number 1 in the queue but getting the IVR played for 22 minutes.
The IVR needs reviewing

author: Blessed Patient
title: Positive experience of the NHS
body: I recently had multiple stays in Ayr hospital, and received a high level of care from everyone I came into contact with. I was cared for by A+E, the CAU, Ambulatory Care, and the CCU, and all staff were professional, but friendly and approachable. They also accommodated me to have my 4 month old baby with me, which was a huge relief to me, and felt like truly person centred care. I especially want to thank Dr Chong for his ongoing care, I cannot praise him highly enough for his fantastic bedside manner, his commitment and dedication to ensure I receive the correct treatment, and his sensitive and empathetic approach. I am truly grateful, and very thankful for NHS Ayrshire and Arran.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: very long waiting times
body: Antenatal appointment. Waited 4 hours to see a midwife that gave me close to zero advice. Felt i waited for truly nothing, then another hour wait to take my blood. Pregnant with no water or food waiting for 5 hours.

author: DOLLYDOODLES
title: Disrespectful staff
body:
Got brought down to A&E after nearly passing out on the ward. This was after according to members of staff I was fitting my pupils were fixated my face had turned blue and my white were white aswell as profusely sweating. Once down in A&E when the nurse told staff what happened and said I was fitting a rude nurse replied ‘she ain’t fitting she’s just shaking’.  
They then done a set of OBS on me took some details and gave me a wrist band. I could then see the A&E staff muttering to each other talking rudely about me saying that there isn’t anything wrong with me, yet they didn’t see what I was like on the ward.  
After the doctor came an ECG was done which I don’t understand as never complained of any chest pain but it was done anyway. This came back clear asked me to then get out of the bed and sit in the chair. I said I’d try and attempt to get out of the bed with no help even though I had nearly collapsed about 45 minutes prior to this. A nurse then came to me and asked if I could walk back to my ward no escort given no nothing. They done absolutely nothing for me even when I was told by a critical care nurse that I needed to have a CT head.  
I have since contacted my GP and has made a referral to the neurologist for a EEG and he was absolutely appalled that nothing more was done for me. If any abnormalities come back that could of been caught in my trip to A&E then I will be taking this further as I thought I was treated disgustingly.

author: Bunty54
title: Clean, efficient busy ward
body:
Clean, efficient busy ward 11. Like the fact staff are doing 12 hour shifts. Greater continuity of care, felt the staff really knew me & time wasn’t wasted on handovers.  
Good general knowledge, but missed the expertise of those who worked within specialist areas ( in my case colorectal expertise)  
Need to give greater guidance to patients on what is acceptable. The person next to me listened to their iPad for hours during the day without using headphones. They also switched it on again at 0230am, I assume because they thought no one could hear it!!! They weren’t confused just very thoughtless & was never challenged by staff.

author: patient122
title: Some of them were lovely
body:
I had been in labour since 8am and went into Treliske at 9pm. I was dilating steadily but contractions slowed down when I got into the birthing pool. They suggested breaking my waters to speed things up so I agreed. By 5 or 6am I was fully dilated but nothing was happening and the midwife was clearly perplexed, tired and wanted me to have it before she finished her shift at 8am. She kept saying "but the head is SO low!". She suggested an intermittent catheter - that my bladder must be full and that was stopping me wanting to push. She fiddled around trying to insert this catheter FOUR times. In the end she had to get a colleague to do it. I am told by my friend who is a nurse, that three attempts at anything is the golden rule. Anyway - it was unpleasant and I wasn't very happy about it but by this point I could hardly speak I was so tired and sore. By 8am a more senior midwife swapped with her and must have realised I needed help as she kept going to the door to speak to someone and eventually transferred me to the delivery ward.  
Once on the delivery ward the obstetrician took one look and in about 30 seconds said "this baby is facing sideways, he won't be coming out without some help". I couldn't believe that no one had realised this, I'd been up for nearly 30 hours and none of the midwives had apparently noticed he was wedged sideways. They suggested an episiotomy and forceps and very rapidly got me into theatre. The obstetrician, head midwife/nurse and the anaesthetist were delightful - professional, funny, sincere and made me feel like I was finally in safe hands. They also didn't muck about and got on with it, which was a huge relief. My baby was 9.8lbs - every midwife I had seen for the last 9 months had said "oh no, it's not a big baby, I can tell by looking at your bump"....  
I can't fault this team and was relieved to finally be in their hands. I do not understand why I wasn't moved earlier? Why didn't any of the midwives know the baby's head was sideways? Why was I left for as long as I was. My baby was delivered at 11am.  
I had lost too much blood to be sent home so had to go to the horror that it the Treliske postnatal ward. I thought it was their job to check on me and my baby, not for me to call them when I needed help. They said the baby needed a feed every three hours. I was exhausted but set my alarm to feed him but he wasn't hungry. I told them this in the morning and was chastised for not waking him up / changing his nappy and making him feed. I had never had a baby before! No one told me this is what I needed to do and I had hoped that the nurses / midwives would take it upon themselves to check on me and my baby through the night. Instead, I was left on my own and then told off in the morning because I didn't know what I was doing.  
One midwife (some of them were lovely) showed me how to feed lying down, then another midwife came in a few hours later and told me off for having the baby in the bed with me. Confused and conflicting advice from the same team. Once the catheter was removed, I was told to pee in a pot and bring it back for them to look at. I did this and proudly brought my pot of pee back and flagged the attention of a maternity support worker to tell her. She said it was nothign to do with her. I said - well, your colleagues told me to do this so here it is". She looked flustered and walked away, pee in hand. Later on I realised she hadn't recorded it because I was asked before I was discharged whether I had managed to pee after the catheter was removed. I had a thermometer shoved in my ear with no warning plenty of times, and every time told my temp was low. When I asked what that meant they said "it could mean an infection but these machines aren't very reliable". When I had heard this line about 6/7 times, I asked them to go and get a machine that worked and for heaven's sake tell me what my temperature was. It was like something out of a sketch show.  
The poor girl opposite me had just had a c section after being in labour for 3 days and when she asked them to help change the baby because she'd been sick, they told her to do it herself! It was appalling. All these poor women in floods of tears, without their partners, feeling like they were an imposition and not being looked after. Not only had we all had a terrible delivery, we'd been awake for HOURS.  
A junior gynaecologist came to see me to feel my uterus and ask me a few questions about bowel movements. When I asked him questions about infection risk, where exactly the incision was etc. he said, honestly, that he was so junior he actually didn't know the answer to a lot of my questions. He was frightfully nice but just clueless and again, I felt neglected and like I wasn't getting professional, experienced care.  
I had to hassle and hustle to be discharged. They said in the morning they were going to discharge me once my iron levels had come back but they had 'paperwork' to do. I wasn't discharged until 8pm and this was after constant constant badgering of staff to ask how long the paperwork might take and if they had spoken to the relevant consultant etc. When I was finally discharged, I was walking up the corridor and realised there was still a canula in my arm and had to ask them to take it out.  
I do understand it must be a staffing issue. There were some lovely midwives on my ward, who had an excellent bedside manner ("do you might if I stick this in your ear to take your temperature" instead of shoving it in with no warning). But, I got the general sense that under-resourcing has led to a level of apathy in the staff and that perhaps there is a systemic problem with the culture there. Bedside manner costs nothing. Hiring maternity support workers (surely there are plenty of people in Cornwall who are in desperate need of a job and not qualified midwives) who can change sheets, pass babies, check in on the women, take blood pressure - surely?! Instead, from some of the staff, I witnessed sloppy, slapdash, cavalier and simply unemphatic behaviour.  
I was relieved to be home but then proceeded to bleed large lumpy blood clots from my urethra - apparently from the trauma of the catheterisation. I adore my baby and yes, the stitches hurt and I was tired etc. but the thing I was in tears about every evening for a week was the intermittent catheterisation that caused this bleeding. I felt I had been prodded and poked by someone who clearly wasn't competent enough to get it right in three goes.  
I knew Treliske postnatal ward had a bad rep - it's all over the internet but I thought since it had been in special measures, that it would be OK if I ended up there. It must be a management and culture problem.

author: Happy New Parents
title: A perfect birthing experience for Mum, Dad and baby
body:
In June 2020 we gave birth to our first child. From our arrival at 16:00, through the birth an hour and a half later, and until our departure later that evening, midwife Alison and student midwife Sophie gave us absolutely first class care.  
Alison was very respectful of our birth plan, and where it wasn't possible to follow it, she was considerate and clearly explained our options. She was calm, kind and encouraging, and we never felt pressured into anything we didn't want to do. The result was a very positive birth experience.  
Sophie was a hugely calming influence; she was aware of the Hpynobirthing programme we were following so talked us through the relaxation and breathing techniques. She was professional, confident and knowledgeable about all aspects of the birth and care of our baby; noting she is still a student makes this even more impressive.  
The result of both Alison and Sophie's considerate and professional care was a perfect birthing experience for Mum, Dad and baby; thank you very much.

title: Understanding practice
body: I have been to gp surgery first 4 health group church road several times regarding my health problems,all the staff receptionist are really kind and helpful.doctors are respectful and listen to my problems carefully and understand them.

title: Brilliant baby nurse
body: I went in to get my daughters 16 week jabs and told them she kept vomiting previously when getting the oral rotavirus med however the nurse suggested doing jabs before to open the airway and it worked! She was absolutely brilliant! Fantastic experience!

title: Wonderful experience
body: Day surgery for inguinal hernia in Sandbourne Suite. Wow. What a wonderful experience from start to finish. Every member of staff smiling, positive, welcoming and doing their very best to keep me informed at each stage. So many nurses to thank and each one eager to help and inform. I can not think of any aspect of the welcome, the pre-op time, the surgery and post-op care that could be improved. My consultant and anaesthetist also must be mentioned.  Nurses and staff, consultants and all ancillary staff work long hours and at times under immense pressure and smiles can and may occasionally slip but if the smiles slipped I did not see it.  All so marvellous.  Grateful thanks to all in the Sandbourne Suite. Tea and sandwich was good as well!!!!

readBy.name: The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great practise by the nurse
body: The nurse gave excellent service,she made sure that I was reassured and had catered to my every enquiry she was really caring compared to the other doctors I’ve experienced before and even offered extra informative help.

title: Excellent service especially whilst during a…
body: The surgery have changed to a Telephone First system due to the Coronavirus pandemic but this is much better for me and I had no problem booking a call back from the GP. I spoke to the doctor the same day and my prescription was sent electronically to the chemist. I collected my medication later that same day. I am very pleased with the service from the GP surgery.

title: Very impressed
body: Went for an ultrasound. Firstly,I felt very safe with all the procedures which had been implemented. The young nurse who helped me was so kind and really put me at ease. Thank you . NHS

readBy.name: Wrightington, Wigan and Leigh NHS Trust

title: Very friendly
body: The staff are very professional, despite the pandemic occuring they make you feel comfortable and continue to stick to the guidelines by keeping their distance and providing you with hand sanitizer as soon as you enter the practice.

title: Frustrating Experience
body:
I would just like to share my recent experience with the surgery.  I must say firstly that I appreciate and understand the difficulties of Covid-19 as I  have also been working during the pandemic.  I finally plucked up courage and spoke to a receptionist, asking if I could see a doctor.  I was told that I would get a telephone appointment, which was fine, but this could be anytime between 8.30am - 5.00pm.  I explained to the receptionist that I was still working and could the doctor possibly ring me, before I left for work.  I was told this was not possible and could I be reached by another number.  I explained that I wasn't able leave where I worked during work hours and that I didn't want to discuss my personal details, in front of colleagues.  The receptionist said she would put me down anyway, which I thought was a waste of time for the doctor and myself not being there after 10.00am, so I declined the appointment.  As mentioned not everybody has been furloughed and of course the surgery is not open, on a Saturday.  I am hoping that the problem I have is not going to get worse and become life threatening, but who knows, at my age?  Again, I appreciate the difficult situation we are all experiencing at the moment, but surely there must be some leeway, regarding individual patients needs?
From a worried and frustrated patient.

title: Never enough appointments. Rude admin staff who…
body:
The admin staff are atrocious. Never able to book an annpointment easily. Takes hours of phoning to get hold of the practice. When you finally get an answer, they are rude, and always can't do anything to help you; their hands are perpetually "tied" no matter the issue. 

Admin staff contradict each other, and then shout at you for fulfilling instructions given by someone else. 

Phone lines always drop. 

When the 4 or 5 booking are released online on the day, they are over subscribed.

title: ANSWER YOUR PHONE
body: I have been on hold for 30 minutes and counting, I am currently on hold whilst typing this. you say you have 4 receptionists answering the calls, this twice today I have been on hold for half an hour and no answer. grand

title: where are they
body: they do not seem to be in the Stevenage building and they don't answer the phone. Rang Enfield the don't know where they are either

title: Excellent support at very difficult time.
body: I am a carer for my elderly mother who is registered at this practice. I do not live locally so have to manage medical problems by telephone. During the coronavirus crisis I have found the reception staff & practitioners (Drs, nurses, district nurses) to be consistently helpful, competent & timely in their responses. The care has been excellent & it has made the situation so much less stressful for me. Thank you all.

title: So helpful
body: I have recently had contact with the practice regarding my elderly fathers health. The reception staff that I have spoken to could not have been more helpful and polite and one particular GP has been simply outstanding. Thank you all for making a difficult time a little less challenging.

title: Radiotherapy Treatment - A2 machine
body:
The staff were very compassionate, considerate and skilful; reassuring too.  They stressed that should I have any queries or concerns to get in touch with them and gave me a direct line number.  I did contact them for advice and the response was speedy (answering the phone) and the advice was given in an unhurried and clear manner.

To know that I had such expertise available was such a relief at what was inevitably a very stressful time both for my wife and me.  

A huge thank you to all the radiographers on the A2 machine!

readBy.name: University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust

title: Excellent Support Service
body: Today (1-Jul-2020) I visited the PCEU for a routine consultation and procedure (I normally use RBH Reading).  The procedure was the same.  I was impressed with the help and support I received both on arrival, and on departure where the non-medical staff ensured that my transport arrived and that it, and I, were in the same place at the same time.  Well done - despite the virus!!!

title: Very inefficient
body:
I filled in an online form (econsult) and attached two photos of a problem I am having with my eye. 

I got a call out of the blue from a PA. I could not answer the phone at that time and when I logged into the NHS App, that I said I have missed my ‘appointment’.  No appointment was made so I am a bit surprised by this. The PA tried another time to call out of the blue and again I was not able to answer the call.  

I do wonder why you do not offer video appointments for patients?  I recently returned from New Zealand and they do video appointments as standard. It seems very inefficient and old fashioned to be using online forms then calling back by phone (and without prior appointment). In my case I just wanted to quickly consult with a GP and if you had online video appointments this would be much easier for all concerned.

I wrote an email to reception complaining and they did call me back and then made an phone appointment with a GP (again with no time given!) and the GP did call me and I was able to take the call when they happened to call. The GP did not seem aware that I had filled in the econsult form. 

Goodness knows how much this level of inefficiency costs the taxpayer and NHS! Multiple calls, emails and forms before even just getting to speak to a medical professional who could help me quickly, once I did finally get to speak to one. 

In this day and age, with all the amazing digital tech we have at our disposal, this is unacceptably wasteful of everyone’s time. Please, embrace all the tools we have to make life easier for us all.

title: Great service
body: left a message and had a call from a Dr within 15 minutes and prescription sent to chemist straight away.  Such a great service during these stressful times.  Thank you do much for all you do

title: Great practice
body:
Good surgery great staff always helpfull
Absolutely a great service from all the staff
At Woodend medical centre tre

title: Helpful
body: Had a telephone appointment earlier today and the service received was helpful from both the reception as well as the GP who rang back a few minutes afterwards.

title: Great Experience
body: The Dr has been so supportive and proactive during a very difficult time for me. I’m very grateful for all his kind efforts.

title: Fantastic serviice
body: Really put my mind at rest by diagnosing my underlying problem and setting things in place to provide a solution

title: very poor service
body:
I sent in an e-consultation on  Tues around  1.30 also emailed very distressing photos of mum in laws eye, containing a large puddle of blood filling most of her eye (91yrs old), she hadn't knocked it at all she woke up like that.
trying to get a consult with a GP just over the phone or just to actually look at the picture was a nightmare, ended up calling the surgery 6 times during the whole afternoon until 6pm, I asked,  and asked for the GP to call my mobile number as I am down as her guardian as someone to discuss on her behalf as she is not very good on the phone, nobody called me back, but the GP actually called my mum in law ina 2 second consultation, asked her how she was, she said fine, he said ok and left it at that, never even consulted me at all, he just left it at that, her eye is in a right mess, I will never ask for a phone call again, I will ask for a home visit from the GP instead to a very frail 91 yr old lady, its an  awful way to treat people, I know we have a problem with covid but it does not have to mean that everyone's health suffers, I work in a surgery and I showed our GP's her eye and they were shocked at the look of it and said there might be some sort of clot underlying somewhere that had caused it but her GP would not even look at it for her

title: Fantastic medical care
body: Doctors, nurses and reception staff All very helpful, caring and professional. They inspire confidence.

title: Extremely caring practise
body: Doctor phoned today and sorted out my concerns sent prescription straight to chemist very cheerful and couldn’t of helped me more she was just lovely 😊 The nurses are terrific too it’s such a helpful surgery

title: I don't know who half these reviews are on about
body:
I haven't been here recently, my last appointment was in Feburary or so, but I am staggered to read some of the comments about lack of appointments and rude receptionists. I can only suggest that the people writing these things are projecting their own attitude and behaviours onto the hardworking, friendly and helpful staff here. 
I have never failed to book an appointment within a reasonable amount of time, and the staff on the desk have always been polite. In fact they have been very patient in trying to find me an appointment to suit around my working hours. The medical staff are also very good here, with thorough consultations and treatment has always been adequate. I was kept waiting a very long time for one appointment but the receptionist did keep popping her head in to apologise for delays. The surgery needs a bit of a freshen up but then don't most NHS facilities? Thanks Oakswell, keep up the good work.

title: Poor treatment from what I assume was a locum
body:
I had an consultation with your duty doctor on 30 June 2020.  I had recently had a hysterectomy and had suffered a post operative infection (not officially diagnosed).  I had also undergone a swab test and some blood tests.  

The duty doctor told me that all the results had come back as normal and that I needed no further treatment. I told him very clearly that I was feeling sick, dizzy and very shakey and that I felt that I could still have an infection at site of the hysterectomy. 

The doctor was dismissive and said I needed no more treatment. I asked what I should do if I still felt so unwell. I asked should I go to A and E.  I again said I thought my problem was connected to my hysterectomy.  At which point the doctor said that I was forcing him into prescribing antibiotics.  He gave me a prescription, with much ill will, and finally said that if I was still ill I should go to A and E, as there we’re no further tests he could do.

The doctor’s opinion was that I forced him to prescribe antibiotics, but I was merely trying to get treatment for a problem that had left me feeling very unwell and frightened.

I understand in these difficult times that it is not possible to have a consultation with the same doctor every time, but I do feel even duty doctors should show some empathy for their patients.

title: Parking
body:
I visited this hospital this morning i drove my mother there.
I saw many signs asking me to register my vehicle registration number to get free parking so accompaned my mother into the hospital (due to her age she is not comfortable using technology) when i arrived in the building I saw the the sign saying the parking permit scheme has been suspended 

There was no signs outside the hospital building telling me of this fact - I had no need to go into the hospital myself I could have stayed in my car 

I was wondering while the scheme is suspended you can cover the signs

title: Empty hospital. Great staff / patient work ratio
body:
Replacement hip joint. Entire team made me very welcome and comfortable. Operating team excellent and surgery excellent so far.
Now starting third week after surgery and walking 4 miles on sticks. All good so far.

title: Phone line
body: I have phone the group practice eight times on different days and have been told that I am “Fifth “ in the queue or third or even first! Only to be cut off every time at the last moment. Appalling set up and does make me wonder if it is a revenue gathering exercise with the phone calls.

title: Better than some private hospitals in all areas
body: Cleaners were exceptionally thorough. The food was excellent and adapted for specific diets. All staff outstandingly professional, kind and caring. My Consultant is not only highly knowledgeable but such a gentleman, makes me feel important.

title: It is what it is
body: Not sure where I can leave a complaint. I normally wouldn’t but I feel the issue needs addressing. I was in a que for my medication with an online exemption form as I had been pregnant but a week before I had got around to collecting my medication I had miscarried. The person at the door said she thought I had to pay and I said I wasn’t sure as I had miscarried. I had to say this in front of a que of people and then the person went and loudly asked the question to the pharmacist and then awkwardly charged me. Following this encounter I had a break down in the car and have since been on the NHS website which states you do not have to pay for prescription even if you miscarry for up to a year so the staff at callington should be informed of this. It was very distressing and no emotional compassion was showed by staff what so ever. Not even a kind word to say I’m sorry for your loss just oh you have to pay. Whilst I know we are under a lot of stress perhaps training in kind etiquette could be given to the staff. It really has upset me to the extent I don’t want to go to the doctors again.

title: Exemplary care
body:
I was taken into Allerton Ward Torbay last week with acute recurring stomach pains. The assessment on arrival was completed quickly. My stay in ward 07 was memorable. The skill and professionalism was superb. All the staff had time for me with empathy and humour. I was kept informed at all stages and was able to ask questions
An incredible team inclusive of the theatre team and those providing our meals
We are blessed with this level of care and healing
Thank you

title: Very useless
body: I am disgusted my dad has no internet and they don’t wanna help get his heart tablets very disgusting! The woman on the phone was very rude and blunt and didn’t wanna help. The time of this call was 5:09 she didn’t give her name. date of day 1/6/20

title: Great staff
body: The staff at this practice have always been extremely helpful and go above and beyond to help whenever ive needed it. Even throughout the pandemic they have continued to work and provide the best care at these difficult times

title: Excellent care
body:
I attended for an ICD box change and a new lead.

Everything was explained clearly and sympathetically.  

Care was excellent both in the lab and on the ward.

And all this in the midst of the pandemic

title: Excellent and caring
body: I have a disability which means that I use an extensive range of services of the Trust. I have found my experience to always be supportive and comprehensive. I trust their work implicitly

readBy.name: University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust

title: Positive experience
body:
I had ignored the letter for two weeks about my child’s 1 year injections not wanting to go anywhere near a doctors surgery with everything going on with covid 19 and feeling very uneasy, until getting a call off the nurse. 
I cannot praise the nurse enough, my concerns were took on board, I was given options in a completely understanding and caring way. 
The process was safe and we didn’t come into contact with anybody apart from the nurse who had full ppe to ensure both the nurse and us were completely safe. An all round positive and reassuring process.

title: Useless for prescriptions
body:
Following on from my previous review...a repeat prescription with no changes at all has been cocked up for the fourth month in a row.
The Dispensary, which seems to have more staff than the rest of the surgery put together, can't do anything on time or without mistakes. They need chasing and chasing before grudgingly processing a prescription. You have to admire their utter crass incompetence.

title: Keep vaccine update children
body: Same as normal advised keep vaccines upto date for my son refused by surgery advised to pay privately at a pharmacy but NHS website says it free for under 25 other surgery do it but not Sheepcote always the same level service 😞

title: fantastic staff
body:
Would like ot say a big thank you to all the staff who took care of me on 1st july, they where fantastic and made me so relaxed highly recommended, Big thank you to the nurse who look after me room 125 ward 1 can't remember her name but thats off to her and everyone else who works there , best service thank you all for your hard work at this time and providing a fantastic service 

Stay safe and a big thank you 
James Mawtus

title: This is the worst practice I have had to deal with
body: I cannot believe how difficult you are making it for me to get a repeat prescription for my wife who has dementia this practice causes me more headaches trying to get a monthly repeat your web site is useless and trying to get a receptionist to help me order a prescription is impossible all I want is to either phone up or register to have them ordered and delivered to my home.I hope you are happy with my misery because that is what it is every month digusted husband already under tremendous stress trying to look after a dementia patient

title: Excellent treatment
body: Attended York Hospital for a Vascular  AAA Operation on the 18th May 2020.During this time I was seen by staff at various departments and Wards, Radiology Dept for scans , Intensive care following the operation  and the high independance ward which I believe is ward 11. I was impressed how proffesional and caring all those involved were, in particular the 2 Vascular surgeons ,Anaesthetist, and theatre team . I was ready to return home 7 days after the operation which is amazing considering it was major surgery and I cannot thank those involved enough. Well done YDH. - C Brown.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Discrimination to the disabled
body: Really disappointed that there was no support to guide my visually impaired father unto their practise. They refused to even verbally guide him to the room, and left him waiting outside the building. My mother couldn't even walk him to the room. This is discrimation at it's finest. This should have been thought about before his appointment. This caused a lot of upset and they left feeling very let down. It took a lot of courage for my father to come out of the house to the appointment. Disgusting.

title: Amazing Staff
body: I went in for my procedure today extremely nervous and not knowing what I expect. I was greeted by a lovely lady who got me some water and reassured me and talked me through what was going to happen. I have been very sick and they quickly administered anti sickness and calmed me down. My surgeon came to see me before I went in for my procedure and introduced herself which was lovely. I had 3 wonderful ladies performing my surgery and they all made me feel so comfortable and kept me calm by talking to me throughout, I don’t think I would have got through it otherwise. Recovery was wonderful. I was taken to a quiet area and there was a few nurses in there who got me a drink and sat and chatted with me which made me feel very safe and happy in their care. BPAS Bournemouth provided me with an absolutely fantastic service. I felt well looked after and relaxed in their care. God forbid anything happened like this in the future - I would go straight back to them and recommend them to anyone. Thank you too all of the staff over at the Bournemouth clinic. You truly do such a fantastic job and you have my biggest thanks❤️hopefully I can bring you in a big box of biscuits to say thanks properly once all of this Covid stuff is over!
